paragraphs.text: Amnesia, not immigration, is our problem.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: It has been a grim start for 2015 as far as European tolerance is concerned
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mosques have been attacked in Sweden
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Demonstrations continue in Germany against the "Islamisation of the west"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And antisemitism is on the rise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We knew something nasty had been unleashed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when the European elections last year produced a surge of populist xenophobic parties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many explanations have been given: the economic crisis, unemployment, the disenfranchisement of the middle classes, anxieties fed by globalisation
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Pointing fingers at strangers or supposed intruders has become almost an automatic reflex
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Anti-immigration parties are having a field day
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All our problems come from the outside, from some kind of invasion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that's how the narrative goes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In France the novelist Michel Houellebecq is making headlines with a new book imagining the election in 2022 of a Muslim president
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There are, it is true, signs of a democratic revival against racism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In solidarity with Muslims, some citizens have been demonstrating in European cities
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It is perhaps only when the worst happens- arson attacks on mosques, or neo-Nazi groups in the streets - that people start mobilising for common decency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the trend is worrisome indeed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europeans seem to be grappling with this one question: how do I live alongside people of a different cultural background, the Other?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In times like this, literature and history can help us see things more clearly
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I turned to the Polish writer Ryszard Kapuscinski
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who spent most of his life travelling across the developing world and reflecting on how Europeans relate to that huge part of the global population that is non- European, and much poorer than Europeans
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In his book The Other, Kapuscinski - who had flaws as a journalist, but certainly didn't lack curiosity for different cultures- points out how difficult it is for inhabitants of the old continent to accept that "the map of the world has changed" since decolonisation in the 1960s
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: After dominating the globe for hundreds of years
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Europeans still have trouble dealing with the fact that they have become less central, less overpowering
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And yet it is a paradox
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because Europe produced arguably the first world citizen open to discovering and appreciating foreign cultures: the Greek historian Herodotus, 2,500 years ago
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I can hear the cringing
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: how delusional and idealistic it is to bring Herodotus into a 21st-century debate on immigration
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: roots matter
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: ,then
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Europeans must look at themselves more closely
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Things were never stable, nor populations fixed in stone
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europe is after all the appendix of a great and contrasted landmass
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: it was always meant to be a crossroads
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We may be baffled by changes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there were times when we lived with much more diversity in our midst
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Tony Judt is great to read on this
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In his book Postwar, he recalls how"the European continent was once a complex tapestry of languages, religions, communities, and nations that overlapped
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Many of its cities - including some of the smallest, at the intersection of old and new imperial borders, such as Trieste, Sarajevo, Salonica, Czernowitz, Odessa, Vilnius - were truly multicultural, with Catholics, Orthodox, Muslims, Jews and others mingling."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Judt goes on:"Between 1914 and 1945, however, this Europe was reduced to ashes."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As a result of war, occupation, border changes, expulsions and genocide, most people ended up living among people like them, in different states
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: During the cold war, the two halves of Europe lived in "hermetic national enclaves" - a world of homogeneity, notes Judt
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In the 1960s immigrants arrived in western Europe to provide a workforce, most from former colonies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Judt calls this a "new presence of 'others' living in Europe", including the millions of Muslims in today's EU
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He says this presence "has outlined not only Europe's discomfort as it is faced with a renewed and growing diversity, but also the ease with which the 'other' dead of Europe's past had crept out of people's minds"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: So there it is
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: today's intolerance has its roots not just in economic frustration, but in amnesia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Since 1989 many of Europe's centres have become"cosmopolitan global cities, whether they like it or not", writes Judt
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Note the"whether they like it or not"
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: This book was published 10 years ago, as if in anticipation of what we see today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The historian's message is that Europe's future is multicultural
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its core values are about being open to the Other
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The only time Europeans experienced relative demographic homogeneity - that era of supposed tranquillity - was in the wake of Hitler's and Stalin's devastations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Such thoughts might not be enough to calm the anti-Muslim crowds
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: .But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they could help
paragraphs.label: assumption
